content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a hard time sleeping lately. My mind just won't stop racing at night, and it's starting to take a toll on me. I feel stressed about work and other things, and I just don’t know how to manage it. My partner encouraged me to talk to someone, so here I am.

That sounds like a lot to carry. It takes strength to open up and explore how you're feeling, so it's great that you’re willing to do so. Stress and sleepless nights can make everything feel heavier. What do you think might be contributing to all of this, and how is it affecting you day to day?

I think it’s mostly work stress. I’ve been worried about getting fired, and I just can’t stop thinking about how I’d manage to support my family if that happened. It’s like this constant loop in my head every night, and then I try to distract myself by scrolling on my phone, but it doesn’t really help. I just feel exhausted all the time.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of responsibility and worry, especially about supporting your family. That loop of thoughts can be so draining, and the scrolling might feel like temporary relief but doesn’t really give the peace you're looking for. It seems like you're trying to find ways to cope, even if they’re not easing the stress completely. How important is it for you to find ways to feel more rested and manage the stress?

It’s really important because I feel like my lack of sleep is making everything worse. I need to be able to focus at work to hold onto my job, and I also want to be present for my family. I feel like I’ve been so irritable and distant lately, and I hate that. I just don’t know where to start fixing this.

You really care about doing well at work and being there for your family, and it's clear this situation is impacting both. Feeling irritable and distant must be tough, especially when those connections matter so much to you. It’s completely normal to feel unsure about how to start when everything feels overwhelming. What do you think would be the first step toward moving into a better place with stress and sleep—or what feels like might help even a little?

I honestly don’t know where to start. Maybe figuring out how to stop my mind from racing at night would be a good first step, but I have no idea how to do that. It just feels like once I lie down, everything hits me all at once, and I don’t know how to shut it off.

It’s tough when your mind feels relentless at night, especially because that’s when you’re hoping to find rest. Taking the first step can feel daunting, but recognizing that settling your thoughts might be helpful is already a good start. What helps to quiet your mind during the day, even for a brief moment? Or have you ever had moments where your mind felt calmer?

I honestly can't think of much that helps during the day either. Sometimes if I'm really busy or distracted, it’s less intense, but the worry is always kind of there in the background. It just feels harder at night because there’s nothing to keep my mind busy, and everything feels louder in my head.

That constant background worry must make things feel heavy, and it’s even harder when the distractions are gone at night. It sounds like staying busy helps ease things for a moment, but that might not be a lasting solution. You’re really trying to find a way to quiet all of this and take care of yourself. If things could be better, what would that look like for you—what kind of changes would you hope to see?

I think what I'd hope for is to feel more in control of my thoughts at night so I can actually rest. I want to wake up feeling less exhausted and more clear-headed so I can focus better at work and be more patient and engaged with my family. I just want to feel like myself again, but getting there feels like such a huge uphill climb right now.

Wanting to feel more in control, rested, and like yourself again shows how much you value your well-being and your relationships. It’s clear you have strong reasons for wanting to make that shift, even though it feels overwhelming at the moment. If there was one small thing you could start with—something manageable—to help you feel even a little closer to that, what might that be?

I don’t know… Maybe trying to put my phone down earlier at night could help, but it’s so hard when it feels like the only thing that distracts me. I’m not sure I have the willpower to stick to it, though.

That’s a thoughtful idea—putting the phone down earlier might create some space for your mind to settle, but it also makes sense that it feels hard when it’s been your go-to distraction. The fact that you're considering it suggests you’re open to finding a way to make things better. What do you think could make it easier to try, even if just for one night or a couple of nights?
Maybe setting a time for when I’ll stop using my phone and doing something else instead, like reading or listening to calming music? I’m not sure if that’ll work, but it might be worth a try.

That sounds like a thoughtful and manageable way to start—creating a set time and replacing the scrolling with something calming like reading or music could create a gentler transition into rest. Even trying it for just one or two nights might help you see if it brings some relief. What do you think might motivate you to stick with it, even if it feels challenging at first?

I guess reminding myself that I’m doing this to feel more rested and to be more present for my family could help. It’s hard, but I want to be a better partner and parent, and maybe that would keep me going. I'll try to focus on that.

That’s a powerful motivation—you’re doing this not just for yourself, but also for your family and those connections that mean so much to you. Keeping that focus could help you push through those tough moments as you try something new. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before moving forward with this idea?
No, I think I'm okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me. I'll try the suggestions we talked about and see how it goes.
